blocks.text: January 1, 1953
Nancy and Louise build a snow lady, topped with one of Kitty's old hats, from the snow which fell on the last day of the old year.
A good way to start the New Year: Kathy, Cindy, Gordon, Nancy, Kitty and Louise gather together for a group picture.

blocks.text: January 5, 1953 – Lancaster ABC holds its Annual Banquet at the Arcadia Restaurant. Gordon is toastmaster.
Richard A. Snyder (left), incoming president of Lancaster Chapter is congratulated by Wayne Strasbaugh, the retiring presiden...
New members initiated into the Big Hat Club: (standing) Groenendaal, R. Smith, C. Smith, Mearig; (seated) Strasbaugh and N. Hager.
A wistful Cindy (natural light).

Across Pennsylvania's famed Turnpike from Harrisburg-East Interchange to the Ohio line, a distance on the Turnpike of 249 miles. Weather mild and sunny.

blocks.text: In Wooster, we plan to visit Jimmy and Trudy Buckwalter; discover they have moved to new development with streets not yet paved; try telephone.
Approaching Shelby in late afternoon, a sharp wind has risen with a decided drop in temperature.
Kitty...as we head across the state of Ohio.
Unattractive court house in Columbus City, Ind., which characterizes mid-west county seats.
Uncle Tom Evans visits us in our room at Shelby Inn; we have dinner together.
A bleak morning as we leave Shelby on Friday for final stretch to Chicago.

blocks.text: Tommy and Dotty Wood visit us in our room at Hotel Sherman on Saturday night.
Across Indiana along the main line of the Penna. Railroad.
Two hours with Bob and Dotty Hummel, and son Scott, in Marion, Ind.
Sunday night with Dick and Chotz Andes in Columbus. Kitty's sister, Helen, right.
Lunch with Mrs. Bennett as we near Plymouth, Ind.
Another of the many fine way-side parks which are provided for motorists in Ohio.

blocks.text: Just beyond Braddock's grave, the Old Stage Coach Inn (1816) which overlooks a reconstructed Fort Necessity where the Battle of Great Meadows took place on July 3, 1754. Here Colonials under the command of George Washington, a lad of twenty-one, were forced to surrender to a superior force of French and Indians. This was the first battle in America of the Seven Years War.
End - Trip to Chicago; total mileage 1,509.

An old bridge and mill along the Conoy Creek south of Lobbatka which suggest an Old World location.

blocks.text: The longest covered bridge in Lancaster County (349¹) spans the Conestoga Creek near the New Danville Pike.
February 6, 1953 - Ready to attend the University Club dance at Hotel Brunswick.
The Octararo Valley showing a covered bridge connecting Lancaster-Chester Counties.
Ruins along East Branch of Octaroro Creek at site of Sadsbury Forge #1, which was in operation 1800 to 1880.
Exercise... (above) Kitty participates in a square dance at the Stone Barn. Cindy takes a shot at the bass-left). She hooks her to our garage door.

blocks.text: As last year, the heaviest snow-fall of the season comes early in March. Scene (right) shows a part of the Marietta Pike area from a high point at Ironville.

With all the children in school,
Kitty registers as a substitute teacher and soon gets a call from Manheim Township.

That fur jacket it is scheduled for retirement for the season. Kitty stands before our home in late March.
Marccrhh.

blocks.text: March 29, 1953 - An afternoon's drive into York County along the Susquehanna River.
Accomac Inn

The Wrightsville area with the long concrete bridge. The Wrightsville will have a new one in place within this year, and it's going to be much better than what we've had before.
The old bridge was built during World War II as part of an effort by the U.S. government to improve transportation infrastructure across America.
Cindy and Louisa - Susquehanna at Long Level.

blocks.text: April 17, 1953 - On a business trip to Washington Gordon visits the Lincoln Memorial.

After Washington's defeat at the battle of Brandywine, September 11, 1777, about 500 sick and wounded American soldiers were sent to the Ephrata Cloister for treatment. Several hundred whose names have never been recorded died here and were buried in a common grave. The monument (left) at the outskirts of Ephrata was erected in 1902 in their memory.
A time for eating...Louise, Nancy, Cindy and Kathy have their unposed pictures taken at the dinner table.

blocks.text: May 23 - 27, 1953: A trip to Boston to attend the Annual Conference of the National Office Management Association. Gordon has just been elected president of the Lancaster Chapter. Gordon, John Lingle and Harold Reece represent Educators Mutual Insurance Company. Chrysler sedan – 958 miles.

blocks.text: Acrosssxs the Bear Mountain Bridge, south-east through New York to Connecticut and Merritt Parkway.

The well preserved old village of Guilford, Conn. with many homes dating from the 17th and the 18th centuries. On many of the homes the date of construction and the name of the original owner is recorded. An especially beautiful church is here.
At Madison, another old town, we drive to the edge of Long Island Sound. In the distance is Hammon-dasset State Park.

blocks.text: To reach Newport, R. I., we cross Narragansett Bay via Conanicut Island which connects with the west shore by the long Jamestown Bridge and with Newport by ferry. Conanicut Island is about nine miles long and from one to two miles wide. The island was an early refuge for Quakers and during the Revolutionary War it was occupied by the British.
The Jamestown Bridge.
The harbor at Jamestown.
Craft of the U. S. Navy lie at anchor in the Bay as we ride the ferry to Newport.

blocks.text: Newport, R. I. is as famed for its charm as an old New England town as for its reputation as the summer capital of high society from 1880 into the early 1920's. The mansions erected by the wealth along the rocky shore of the Atlantic are almost beyond belief. In colonial times the town rivalled New York and Boston in importance. Later Southern planters spent their sum- mers here. Finally the town was taken over by Eastern society.
The beach.
Along the rocky southern shore at Newport.

What is it? Even the natives profess not to know. Some claim this Old Stone Tower was built by the Vikings in the 12th century. Others say it is only a windmill erected at a much later date. In any case, it is a familiar picture in grade school history books.

Two of the fabulous homes built by the wealth during th "Golden Age" of Newport. One home (top picture) is now a Catholic school for girls; the lower picture is The Breakers, built by the Vanderbilts at a cost of $3,000,000. Newports's homes must be seen to be believed.

blocks.text: Boston is one of the most interesting cities in America. It is the largest city in New England, rich in history and devoted to art and culture. Many of the old buildings have been preserved, together with the narrow, tortuous streets which create a maddening traffic problem. It should be seen on foot.

blocks.text: Boston Common, now in the heart of Boston, is nearly fifty acres in area. Originally it was a pasture for cows and a training field for militia. Wrongdoers were ducked, whipped and placed in the pillory and stocks. Today it is a hugh park and a forum for free public discussions.
Old shade trees, long walks and benches make the Common an ideal place to relax in the center of a big city.
Some of the less fortunate citi-zens asleep on the grass.
The Public Garden Gardens next to the Commons are the oldest in America. The famous swan boats are propelled like a bicycle.

blocks.text: The State House, with its gilt dome, overlooks Boston Common. The corner stone was laid in 1795 and Charles Bulfinch was the architect.

The Park Street Church, dedicated 1810, is the finest example of 19th century ecclesiastical architecture in Boston. It stands on "Brimstone Corner", so called from the storage of brimstone in the basement for the manufacture of powder in 1812, although some profess to believe the fiery sermons gave the corner this name. Both William Lloyd Garrison and Charles Sumner spoke here, and "America" was first publicly sung.
Louisberg Square, actually a tiny oval park, privately owned by the old families still living in the tall, narrow houses which surround it on Beacon Hill. Aristocratic Boston at its best.

blocks.text: Faneuil Hall, named for the Boston merchant who presented it to the city, is known as "The Cradle of Liberty" for the many patriotic meetings held there which inspired the people to resist the British and produce the American Revolution. The building is to this day a market house.

The United States Customs House towers 490 ft. near the water-front.
ffroontt...
Right - "Old Dobbin" still has his day along the water front. The dock area is picturesque with a strong odor of fish.

blocks.text: Left - The Old State House was erected in 1713, and rebuilt in 1748 after the interior was destroyed by fire. The Square in front was the gathering place of the populace from Colonial times. Here occurred the Boston Massacre in 1770, and from the eastern balcony the Declaration of Independence was proclaimed.
Right – King's Chapel, dedicated 1754, was intended to be the home of the Church of England in America. The granite in the present walls was the first quarried in this country.
Left – Paul Revere House, the oldest home in Boston is furnished as it was when its famous owner lived there. Built sometime after 1676.
Right - The Old South Meeting House, erected 1729, was the scene of many a fiery denunciation of British rule in America. The signal for Boston's famous Tea Party in America.
The Old City area near the water front has narrow and twisting streets. Italian immigrants dominate this area today. Live snails are available at 30¢ per pound.

blocks.text: August, 1953
Nancy is one of seventeen Girl Scouts who spend a week at a house party at Mount Gretna. On a visit, we have a picnic with the Claude Smith family.
August 8, 1953 - An afternoon at Willow Grove with James and his family. We get unlimited rides on all the amusements for seventy-five cents, which keep the children on the move constantly.

New fathers - Frank Bitzer and Bill Minotti.
Tom Donnelly changes his clothes in a barrel after rescuing a soft ball.
A few members take to sports...most are satisfied to sit and talk.

blocks.text: September 5, 6, 7, 1953 (Labor Day week-end). A new experience - with fourteen other families, we undertake "family camping" at the Girl Scout camp at Furnace Hills in northern Lancaster County. All six Landreths sleep in one tent, with meals secured at Holly Hall. We arrive at camp on Saturday afternoon, and barely unpack our clothes and prepare our tent, when rain begins to fall. The rain continues that evening, all night, all day Sunday, all Sunday night...and it only abates as we prepare to leave for home on Monday morning.

Five families comprise the Hillcrest unit - the Gilbos, the Maurers, the Cairns, the Sauders and the Landreths. Louise stands to the right of the sign, with Nancy, Cindy, Kathy, Kitty and Gordon arrayed to the right of her. Each family has its own tent. Picture taken on Monday morning after the rain had ceased to fall.

Most of our activities are centered in Holly Hall,
where our meals are served. Square dancing, nature
lectures, bridge and Sunday morning services keep
the groups occupied. Picture, directly below, of
Holly Hall taken Sunday morning when the sun put
in its appearance.
End - family camping.

One of the rapidly disappear-ing one room school houses of Lancaster County.

The children are given a surprise Halloween part on Oct-
ober 31.

blocks.text: November 6-7-8, 1953 (Friday, Saturday and Sunday) - A trip to Columbus, Ohio, with the children (they miss one day of school), to visit Kitty's sister, Helen, and Chotz and Dick Andes. Trip out and back the same way: Penna. Turnpike; to Washington, Pa.; R#40 to Columbus. Total mileage - 850. Kitty and Gordon, Chotz and Dick see Ohio State lose to Michigan State 28 - 13. (Michigan State later chosen to play in the Rose Bowl).
A wayside park in Ohio.

Dick is a busy-beaver,
watching the game with an ear glued to a portable radio for scores on other games.
A capacity crowd of 73,000 sees the game played under overcast skies with light rain and snow flurries.

blocks.text: November 20–21, 1953 - Harold Reece, Haroold Diffenderffer and Gordon, as president of Lancaster Chapter, represent Educators Mutual Insurance Company at the National Office Management Business Conference at the University of Maryland. Conference sessions Friday afternoon and Saturday morning; address by Senator Williams of Delaware at Washington's Hotel Statler on Friday evening; football game between Maryland and Alabama on Saturday afternoon.

Friday night spent at one of these cot-tages at the Lord Calvert Inn. Gordon is dressed for the football game.
Gordon Innn.
Final score: Maryland 21; Alabama O. As a reward, Maryland is named the #1 team in the Nation, a possibition it retains.
Maryland's cheering section displays a huge "M". The dark figures are the Air Corps cadets attending the school.
